items.title: Generate Access Token from Another Microservice
items.body:
I would like to hear your insights regarding my dilemma that made me stuck for days.

Here's the issue:

I have an adapter class called "RiderAvailClientAdapter" which implements my connection to another microservice called RAVA.

The problem is I can't connect to the said service since it has a security token.

Now I created an implementation that would solve the issue. Solution is that I implemented a generateAuthToken method in my "AuthClientAdapter" that will handle the generation of token coming from another microservice called AUTH (Which the service that handles all of the security)

Issue: It can't generate the said token from my client api but my username and password as request body are being read within the app. I tested the same username and password in postman for the api I wanted to connect to and it worked. In short, it works in POSTMAN but NOT within my app.

FF are the codes

@Component
@Slf4j
@RequiredArgsConstructor
public class RiderAvailClientAdapter implements RiderAvailabilityRESTClientPort {
            
 private final RiderAvailClientProxy riderAvailClientProxy;
            
 private final AuthClientAdapter authClientAdapter;
            
 @Override
 public RiderAvailabilityStatusDto getRiderStatus(String riderNumber) {
 String accessToken = authClientAdapter.getAccessToken();
 return riderAvailClientProxy.getRiderStatus(riderNumber, "Bearer " + accessToken);
  }
}



@Component
@RequiredArgsConstructor
@Slf4j
public class AuthClientAdapter implements AuthClientPort {

   private final AuthClientProxy authClientProxy;

   private final AuthServiceConfiguration authServiceConfiguration;

   private String accessToken;


    /**
     * 240000 = 4 min: will generate new token after each 4min.
     */
    @Scheduled(fixedRate = 240000)
    public void generateAuthToken() {
        log.info("Generating access token...");
        LoginRequestDto loginRequest = new LoginRequestDto();
        loginRequest.setUsername(authServiceConfiguration.getUsername());
        loginRequest.setPassword(authServiceConfiguration.getPassword());
        try {
            LoginResponseDto loginResponseDTO = authClientProxy.login(loginRequest);
            accessToken = loginResponseDTO.getAccessToken();
            log.info("access token generated successfully...");
        } catch (InvalidRequestException e) {
            log.error("Error while generating access token : ", e);
        }
    }

    public String getAccessToken() {
        return accessToken;
    }
}

answers.body_markdown:
# iOS

Assuming native spec you posted is correct (I'm not really familiar with TypeScript + Codegen duo) when you run `pod install` command in your `ios/` directory codegen should generate `EventEmitters` cpp file (+ header) in `React-Codegen` pod (you can see below how to find it in XCode)

[link to the screenshot with Pods structure][1]

You can then use these classes in your `Objective-C++` code to emit the events:

```objective-c++
if (_eventEmitter != nullptr) {
    std::dynamic_pointer_cast<const facebook::react::$$NAME OF YOUR EVENT EMITTER TYPE$$>(_eventEmitter)
        ->onEvent(facebook::react::$$NAME OF YOUR EVENT EMITTER TYPE::OnEvent{.value = $$VALUE$$});
}
```

See links below to see how it is done in [`react-native-screens`](https://github.com/software-mansion/react-native-screens)

1. [Native component spec in `Flow`](https://github.com/software-mansion/react-native-screens/blob/main/src/fabric/ScreenNativeComponent.js)
2. [Event emission in Obj-C++ code](https://github.com/software-mansion/react-native-screens/blob/cc5de7ba28e90ecce9bbb3464ef0a625eaae032f/ios/RNSScreen.mm#L316-L334)
3. [Event exposure in screen manager](https://github.com/software-mansion/react-native-screens/blob/cc5de7ba28e90ecce9bbb3464ef0a625eaae032f/ios/RNSScreen.mm#L1175) - I'm not quite sure if this line is necessary, haven't tested it out yet.

# Android

1. To trigger codegen just run native build. 
2. Define native event class as [done here](https://github.com/software-mansion/react-native-screens/blob/main/android/src/main/java/com/swmansion/rnscreens/events/ScreenAppearEvent.kt)
3. Take a look here for [how to dispatch event](https://github.com/software-mansion/react-native-screens/blob/ce84df60227a02e1e505e1a494ea1ca829788d58/android/src/main/java/com/swmansion/rnscreens/ScreenFragment.kt#L198-L215)
4. [Export your event types](https://github.com/software-mansion/react-native-screens/blob/ce84df60227a02e1e505e1a494ea1ca829788d58/android/src/main/java/com/swmansion/rnscreens/ScreenViewManager.kt#L164-L181)



  [1]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/x52mg.png

answers.title: How to do event handling for android and iOS in react native's new architecture for fabric components?
answers.body:
Indeed the documentation is so terse right now, not even sure if I'm using the new architecture or not, but its working.

Here are the steps for Android in Java flavour.

Step 1 - Define the Specs

type CustomEvent = Readonly<{
  status: string;
}>;

export interface NativeProps extends ViewProps {
  onStatusChange?: DirectEventHandler<CustomEvent>;
}

Step 2 - Define Event Class

public class CustomEvent extends Event<CustomEvent> {

    public static final String EVENT_NAME = "topCustomEvent";
    private String status;

    CustomEvent(int viewId, String _status) {
        super(viewId);
        this.status = _status;
    }

    @Override
    public String getEventName() {
        return EVENT_NAME;
    }

    @Override
    public void dispatch(RCTEventEmitter rctEventEmitter) {
        super.dispatch(rctEventEmitter);
    }

    @Override
    protected WritableMap getEventData() {
        WritableMap event = Arguments.createMap();
        event.putString("status", this.status);
        return event;
    }
}

Step 3 - Export/Register Event Type in ViewManager class by overriding its getExportedCustomDirectEventTypeConstants method.

@Override
public @Nullable
Map getExportedCustomDirectEventTypeConstants() {
  Map<String, Object> export = super.getExportedCustomDirectEventTypeConstants();
  if (export == null) {
    export = MapBuilder.newHashMap();
  }
  export.put(CustomEvent.EVENT_NAME, MapBuilder.of("registrationName", "onStatusChange"));
  return export;
}

Step 4- Create dispatchEvent method, call it wherever need to pass event to JS.

private void dispatchEvent(String status) {
    EventDispatcher mEventDispatcher = UIManagerHelper.getEventDispatcherForReactTag((ReactContext)this.ctx, getId());
    mEventDispatcher.dispatchEvent(new CustomEvent(getId(), status));
}

Step 5 - Setup callback in JS where events are to be processed.

onStatusChange={(event) => {console.log('ontatusChange: '+event.nativeEvent.status);}}

Step 6 - Build App, codgen should occur as explained here.

items.title: How to do event handling for android and iOS in react native's new architecture for fabric components?
items.body:
I am trying to create a Fabric component. I have got it working for the most part. The only issue I am facing is I am not able to get click listener to work for a fabric component.

I created a spec file

import type {HostComponent, ViewProps} from 'react-native';
import type {DirectEventHandler} from 'react-native/Libraries/Types/CodegenTypes';
import codegenNativeComponent from 'react-native/Libraries/Utilities/codegenNativeComponent';

type Event = Readonly<{
  value: string;
}>;

interface NativeProps extends ViewProps {
  text: string;
   onClickHandler?: BubblingEventHandler<Event>; ////Event name should start with on
}

export default codegenNativeComponent<NativeProps>(
  'MyButtonView',
) as HostComponent<NativeProps>;

For android my fabric component looks like as follows

public class MyButtonView extends androidx.appcompat.widget.AppCompatButton {

    public MyButtonView(Context context) {
        super(context);
        configureViews();
    }

    private void configureViews(){
        setBackgroundColor(Color.YELLOW);
        setOnClickListener(view -> {
            onReceiveNativeEvent();
        });
    }

answers.body_markdown:
Finally I find the reason

Method `request.setEndpoint` auto add a slash to the end of endpoint

Exp

`https://domain/path/execute`
=> `https://domain/path/execute/`

I fix it by use method `request.setResourcePath`

```
request.setEndpoint("https://domain");
request.setResourcePath("/path/...);
```

answers.body_markdown:
I assume that you are using some kind of IDE, Eclipse or IntelliJ, or whatever. How IDE works is that it is an isolated ecosystem with already predefined JDK/JRE.

I know for a fact when you install a new Eclipse and if you 

1. Right-click on your project

2. Properties

3. Java Build Path

4. Libraries Tab

5. Click on JRE System Library

6. Click on Edit

7. Installed JRE

In that window, Eclipse will have one of the latest JDKs set as a default, which has nothing to do with the JDK that you have installed on your system.
So for example, if you downloaded the latest Eclipse it will have the latest JDK set there that is part of Eclipse, and that is the value that needs to be deleted, and you explicitly set JDK that you want to use, that is 17 in your example.
The same goes for the IDE compiler version, you also need to check if it has the correct value, which is 17 in your example.

Eclipse has Installed JRE and Java Compiler, IntelliJ has SDKs and Java Compiler.

As of IntelliJ places for JDK

1. File > Settings > Build > Compiler > Java Compiler

2. File > Project Settings > SDK and Language level should be 17
 
3. File > Project Settings > Modules > Dependencies tab should have 17 on top  

4. File > Project Settings > Modules > Sources tab should have 17 on top – 


Also please keep in mind that you also need to make sure that you have JDK17 in your pom/gradle file as well.

answers.title: What's the advantage of load() vs get() in Hibernate?
answers.body:
Explanation of semantics of these methods doesn't explain the practical difference between them. Practical rule is the following:

  • Use get() when you want to load an object

  • Use load() when you need to obtain a reference to the object without issuing extra SQL queries, for example, to create a relationship with another object:

    public void savePost(long authorId, String text) {
    Post p = new Post();
    p.setText(text);

    // No SELECT query here. 
    // Existence of Author is ensured by foreign key constraint on Post.
    p.setAuthor(s.load(Author.class, authorId));

    s.save(p);
}

answers.body_markdown:
From the "Java Persistence with Hibernate" book, page 405:
> The one difference between get() and load() is how they indicate that
> the instance could not be found. **If no row with the given identifier**
> value exists in the database, **get() returns null**. The **load() method
> throws an ObjectNotFoundException**. It’s your choice what
> error-handling you prefer.
> 
> More important, t**he load() method may
> return a proxy**, a placeholder, **without hitting the database**. A
> consequence of this is that you may get an ObjectNotFoundException
> later, as soon as you try to access the returned placeholder and force
> its initialization (this is also called lazy loading; we discuss load
> optimization in later chapters.) The load() method always tries to
> return a proxy, and only returns an initialized object instance if
> it’s already managed by the current persistence context. In the
> example shown earlier, no database hit occurs at all! The **get() method
> on the other hand never returns a proxy, it always hits the database**.
>
> You may ask why this option is useful—after all, you retrieve an
> object to access it. It’s common to obtain a persistent instance to
> assign it as a reference to another instance. For example, imagine
> that you need the item only for a single purpose: to set an
> association with a Comment: aComment.setForAuction(item). If this is
> all you plan to do with the item, a proxy will do fine; there is no
> need to hit the database. In other words, when the Comment is saved,
> you need the foreign key value of an item inserted into the COMMENT
> table. The proxy of an Item provides just that: an identifier value
> wrapped in a placeholder that looks like the real thing.
answers.title: What's the advantage of load() vs get() in Hibernate?
answers.body:
From the "Java Persistence with Hibernate" book, page 405:

The one difference between get() and load() is how they indicate that the instance could not be found. If no row with the given identifier value exists in the database, get() returns null. The load() method throws an ObjectNotFoundException. It’s your choice what error-handling you prefer.

More important, the load() method may return a proxy, a placeholder, without hitting the database. A consequence of this is that you may get an ObjectNotFoundException later, as soon as you try to access the returned placeholder and force its initialization (this is also called lazy loading; we discuss load optimization in later chapters.) The load() method always tries to return a proxy, and only returns an initialized object instance if it’s already managed by the current persistence context. In the example shown earlier, no database hit occurs at all! The get() method on the other hand never returns a proxy, it always hits the database.

You may ask why this option is useful—after all, you retrieve an object to access it. It’s common to obtain a persistent instance to assign it as a reference to another instance. For example, imagine that you need the item only for a single purpose: to set an association with a Comment: aComment.setForAuction(item). If this is all you plan to do with the item, a proxy will do fine; there is no need to hit the database. In other words, when the Comment is saved, you need the foreign key value of an item inserted into the COMMENT table. The proxy of an Item provides just that: an identifier value wrapped in a placeholder that looks like the real thing.

answers.body_markdown:
When Load is called it returns a Proxy object. Actual select query is still not fired. When we use any of the mapped property for the first time the actual query is fired. If row does not exist in DB it will throw exception. e.g.
 
    Software sw = ( Software )session.load(Software.class, 12);
Here sw is of proxy type. And select query is not yet called. 
in Eclipse debugger you may see it like

    sw Software$$EnhancerByCGLIB$$baf24ae0  (id=17)	
       CGLIB$BOUND         true	
       CGLIB$CALLBACK_0	CGLIBLazyInitializer  (id=23)	
       CGLIB$CALLBACK_1	null	
       CGLIB$CONSTRUCTED	true	
       id                  null	
       prop1               null	
       softwareprop        null	


when I use

     sw.getProp1()
the select query is fired. And now proxy now knows values for all the mapped properties. 

Where as when get is called, select query is fired immediately. The returned object is not proxy but of actual class. e.g.

    Software sw = ( Software )session.get(Software.class, 12);
Here sw is of type Software itself. If row exists then all mapped properties are populated with the values in DB. If row does not exist then sw will be null.

    sw	Software  (id=17)	
	id	Integer  (id=20)	
	prop1	"prodjlt1" (id=23)	
	softwareprop	"softwrjlt1" (id=27)	

So as always said, use load only if you are sure that record does exist in DB. In that case it is harmless to work with the proxy and will be helpful delaying DB query till the mapped property is actually needed.
answers.title: What's the advantage of load() vs get() in Hibernate?
answers.body:
When Load is called it returns a Proxy object. Actual select query is still not fired. When we use any of the mapped property for the first time the actual query is fired. If row does not exist in DB it will throw exception. e.g.

Software sw = ( Software )session.load(Software.class, 12);

Here sw is of proxy type. And select query is not yet called. in Eclipse debugger you may see it like

sw Software$$EnhancerByCGLIB$$baf24ae0  (id=17) 
   CGLIB$BOUND         true 
   CGLIB$CALLBACK_0 CGLIBLazyInitializer  (id=23)   
   CGLIB$CALLBACK_1 null    
   CGLIB$CONSTRUCTED    true    
   id                  null 
   prop1               null 
   softwareprop        null

when I use

 sw.getProp1()

the select query is fired. And now proxy now knows values for all the mapped properties.

Where as when get is called, select query is fired immediately. The returned object is not proxy but of actual class. e.g.

Software sw = ( Software )session.get(Software.class, 12);

Here sw is of type Software itself. If row exists then all mapped properties are populated with the values in DB. If row does not exist then sw will be null.

sw  Software  (id=17)   
id  Integer  (id=20)    
prop1   "prodjlt1" (id=23)  
softwareprop    "softwrjlt1" (id=27)

So as always said, use load only if you are sure that record does exist in DB. In that case it is harmless to work with the proxy and will be helpful delaying DB query till the mapped property is actually needed.

answers.body_markdown:
- Use get() when you want to load an object
 - Use load() when you need to obtain a reference to the object without
   issuing extra SQL queries, for example, to create a relationship with
   another object:

*Ex:  if you are trying to load /get Empoyee object  where empid=20. But assume record is not available in DB.*

     Employee employee1 = session.load(Employee.class,20);  //Step-1
     system.out.println(employee1.getEmployeeId();       //Step-2  --o/p=20
     system.out.println(employee1.getEmployeeName();       //Step-3 -->O/P:ObjectNotFoundException

  If you use load in step-1 hibernate wont fire any select query to fetch employee record from DB at this moment.At this pint hibernate gives a dummy object ( Proxy ). This dummy object doesnt contain anything. it is new Employee(20).    you can verify this in step-2 
it will print 20. but in step-3 we are trying to find employee information. so at this time hibernate fires a sql query to fetch Empoyee objct. If it is not found in DB.throws ObjectNotFoundException.
  
    Employee employee2 = session.get(Employee.class,20);  //Step-4
for session.get() hibernate fires a sql query to fetch the data from db. so in our case id=20 not exists in DB. so it will return null.
answers.title: What's the advantage of load() vs get() in Hibernate?
answers.body:
• Use get() when you want to load an object
  • Use load() when you need to obtain a reference to the object without issuing extra SQL queries, for example, to create a relationship with another object:

Ex: if you are trying to load /get Empoyee object where empid=20. But assume record is not available in DB.

 Employee employee1 = session.load(Employee.class,20);  //Step-1
 system.out.println(employee1.getEmployeeId();       //Step-2  --o/p=20
 system.out.println(employee1.getEmployeeName();       //Step-3 -->O/P:ObjectNotFoundException

If you use load in step-1 hibernate wont fire any select query to fetch employee record from DB at this moment.At this pint hibernate gives a dummy object ( Proxy ). If it is not found in DB.throws ObjectNotFoundException.

answers.body_markdown:
###### Whats the advantage of load() vs get() in Hibernate? 




|                                               load()                                               |                                     get()                                     |
|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Only use  `load()` method if you are sure that the object exists. It is used for **lazy** loading of entities.                                | If you are not sure that the object exist, then use one of  `get()` methods.It is used for immediate loading of entities. |
| `load()` method will throw an exception if the unique id is not found in the database.               | `get()` method will return `null` if the unique id is not found in the database.  |
| `load()` just returns a proxy by default and database won't be hit until the proxy is first invoked. | `get()` will hit the database immediately.                                      |

 
[source][2]  


**Proxy** means, hibernate will prepare some fake object with given identifier value in the memory without hitting a database.  
[![enter image description here][3]][3]
 

**For Example:**   
If we call `session.load(Student.class,new Integer(107));`   

hibernate will create one fake Student object [row] in the memory with id 107, but remaining properties of Student class will not even be initialized.

[Source][4]


  [1]: http://i.stack.imgur.com/8jVve.jpg
  [2]: http://www.developersbook.com/hibernate/interview-questions/hibernate-interview-questions-faqs-2.php
  [3]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/5HteU.jpg
  [4]: http://www.java4s.com/hibernate/difference-between-hibernate-get-and-load-methods/

load() get()
Only use load() method if you are sure that the object exists. It is used for lazy loading of entities. If you are not sure that the object exist, then use one of get() methods.It is used for immediate loading of entities.
load() method will throw an exception if the unique id is not found in the database. get() method will return null if the unique id is not found in the database.
load() just returns a proxy by default and database won't be hit until the proxy is first invoked. get() will hit the database immediately.

answers.body_markdown:
The performance issues is also major difference between get and load method.

The get() method fetches data as soon as it’s executed while the load() method returns a proxy object and fetches only data when object properties is required.
So that the load() method gets better performance because it support lazy loading.
Whe should use the load() method only when we know data exists because it throws exception when data is not found.
In case we want to make sure data exists we should use the get() method.

In short, you should understand the differential in between, and decide which method is best fix in your application. 

I found this differences on the tutorial [Difference between get and load method in Hibernate][1]


  [1]: http://javabycode.com/java-frameworks/hibernate-4-tutorial/difference-between-get-and-load-method-in-hibernate.html

answers.body_markdown:
**session.load()**:
It will always return a proxy object with the given identity value, even the identity value is not exists in database. However, when you try to initialize a proxy by retrieve it’s properties from database, it will hit the database with select statement. If no row is found, a ObjectNotFoundException will throw.

**session.get()**:
It will always return null , if the identity value is not found in database.

answers.body_markdown:
Get() returns the object by fetching it from database or from hibernate cache whereas load() just returns the reference of an object that might not actually exists, it loads the data from database or cache only when you access other properties of the object.

With load(), we are able to print the id but as soon as we try to access other fields, it fires database query and throws org.hibernate.ObjectNotFoundException if there is no record found with the given identifier. It’s hibernate specific Runtime Exception, so we don’t need to catch it explicitly.
answers.title: What's the advantage of load() vs get() in Hibernate?
answers.body:
Get() returns the object by fetching it from database or from hibernate cache whereas load() just returns the reference of an object that might not actually exists, it loads the data from database or cache only when you access other properties of the object.

With load(), we are able to print the id but as soon as we try to access other fields, it fires database query and throws org.hibernate.ObjectNotFoundException if there is no record found with the given identifier. It’s hibernate specific Runtime Exception, so we don’t need to catch it explicitly.

answers.body_markdown:
Both load() and get() methods are used to retrieve an object from the database in Hibernate. However, there are some key differences between the two methods:

**Object Initialization**: The load() method returns a proxy object that is lazily initialized, meaning that it doesn't actually fetch data from the database until the object is first accessed. On the other hand, the get() method fetches the data from the database immediately and returns the fully initialized object.

**Exception Handling**: If the load() method is called for a non-existent object, Hibernate will throw an ObjectNotFoundException when the proxy is accessed. In contrast, if the get() method is called for a non-existent object, it will return null.

**Database Hit**: If you call load() method, it hits the database immediately only if you access some other property or method of the returned object. But if you call get() method, it hits the database immediately and returns the complete object, which can be accessed by any of its properties or methods.

**Performance**: The load() method can improve performance because it doesn't hit the database immediately, and therefore can reduce the number of queries sent to the database. This can be useful in cases where you need to retrieve a large number of objects. However, if you are certain that the object you are retrieving exists in the database, the get() method can be faster because it fetches the data immediately and avoids the overhead of proxy creation and initialization.

In summary, the main advantage of load() is its lazy initialization, which can help to reduce database hits and improve performance in certain situations. However, it is important to be aware of the potential for ObjectNotFoundException errors when using load(). On the other hand, the get() method is more straightforward and can be faster in cases where you need to fetch the object immediately and don't want to deal with proxy initialization or exceptions.

You can find more about hibernate [here][1].


  [1]: https://medium.com/@bharatshah1992/say-goodbye-to-tedious-sql-queries-why-every-developer-should-start-using-hibernate-4c57d74a874e

Guess not. This timestamp is printed in [private method on `Properties`][1] and there is no property to control that behaviour.

Only idea that comes to my mind: subclass `Properties`, overwrite `store` and copy/paste the content of the `store0` method so that the date comment will not be printed.

*Or* - provide a custom `BufferedWriter` that prints all *but* the first line (which will fail if you add real comments, because custom comments are printed before the timestamp...)


  [1]: http://grepcode.com/file/repository.grepcode.com/java/root/jdk/openjdk/6-b14/java/util/Properties.java#Properties.store0%28java.io.BufferedWriter,java.lang.String,boolean%29

answers.body_markdown:
Given the source code or Properties, no, it's not possible. BTW, since Properties is in fact a hash table and since its keys are thus not sorted, you can't rely on the properties to be always in the same order anyway.

I would use a custom algorithm to store the properties if I had this requirement. Use the source code of Properties as a starter.

answers.title: Properties.store() - suppress timestamp comment
answers.body:
Based on https://stackoverflow.com/a/6184414/242042 here is the implementation I have written that strips out the first line and sorts the keys.

public class CleanProperties extends Properties {
    private static class StripFirstLineStream extends FilterOutputStream {

        private boolean firstlineseen = false;

        public StripFirstLineStream(final OutputStream out) {
            super(out);
        }

        @Override
        public void write(final int b) throws IOException {
            if (firstlineseen) {
                super.write(b);
            } else if (b == '\n') {
                firstlineseen = true;
            }
        }

    }

    private static final long serialVersionUID = 7567765340218227372L;

    @Override
    public synchronized Enumeration<Object> keys() {
        return Collections.enumeration(new TreeSet<>(super.keySet()));
    }

    @Override
    public void store(final OutputStream out, final String comments) throws IOException {
        super.store(new StripFirstLineStream(out), null);
    }
}

Cleaning looks like this

    final Properties props = new CleanProperties();
    try (final Reader inStream = Files.newBufferedReader(file, Charset.forName("ISO-8859-1"))) {
        props.load(inStream);
    } catch (final MalformedInputException mie) {
        throw new IOException("Malformed on " + file, mie);
    }
    if (props.isEmpty()) {
        Files.delete(file);
        return;
    }

    try (final OutputStream os = Files.newOutputStream(file)) {
        props.store(os, "");
    }

answers.title: Properties.store() - suppress timestamp comment
answers.body:
if you try to modify in the give xxx.conf file it will be useful.

The write method used to skip the First line (#Thu May 26 09:43:52 CEST 2011) in the store method. The write method run till the end of the first line. after it will run normally. 

public class CleanProperties extends Properties {
    private static class StripFirstLineStream extends FilterOutputStream {

        private boolean firstlineseen = false;

        public StripFirstLineStream(final OutputStream out) {
            super(out);
        }

        @Override
        public void write(final int b) throws IOException {
            if (firstlineseen) {
                super.write(b);
            } else if (b == '\n') {
                // Used to go to next line if did use this line
                // you will get the continues output from the give file
                super.write('\n');

                firstlineseen = true;
            }
        }

    }


    private static final long serialVersionUID = 7567765340218227372L;

    @Override
    public synchronized Enumeration<java.lang.Object> keys() {
        return Collections.enumeration(new TreeSet<>(super.keySet()));
    }

    @Override
    public void store(final OutputStream out, final String comments)
        throws IOException {
        super.store(new StripFirstLineStream(out), null);
    }
}

answers.title: Properties.store() - suppress timestamp comment
answers.body:
You can handle this question by following this Stack Overflow post to retain order:

Write in a standard order: How can I write Java properties in a defined order?

Then write the properties to a string and remove the comments as needed. Finally write to a file.

ByteArrayOutputStream baos = new ByteArrayOutputStream();
properties.store(baos,null);

String propertiesData = baos.toString(StandardCharsets.UTF_8.name());

propertiesData = propertiesData.replaceAll("^#.*(\r|\n)+",""); // remove all comments

FileUtils.writeStringToFile(fileTarget,propertiesData,StandardCharsets.UTF_8);

// you may want to validate the file is readable by reloading and doing tests to validate the expected number of keys matches
InputStream is = new FileInputStream(fileTarget);
Properties testResult = new Properties();
testResult.load(is);

I was able to use java streams as follows:

      List<String> lines = com.google.common.io.Files.readLines(propertiesFile, Charset.defaultCharset());
      lines.remove(0);
      try (BufferedWriter writer = new BufferedWriter(new FileWriter(propertiesFile))) {
          lines.stream().forEach(p -> {
              try {
                  writer.write(p + "\n");
              } catch (IOException e) {
                  LOG.error(e.getMessage(), e);
              }
          });
      }

As a bonus, it's written in a sorted manner.

                        PathRequest.toH2Console()
                    ).permitAll()
                        
                    .requestMatchers(
                        "/api/auth/login",
                        "/api/auth/logout",
                        "/admin/login",
                        "/error"
                    ).permitAll()
                
            ).formLogin((formLogin) ->
                formLogin
                    .usernameParameter("username")
                    .passwordParameter("password")
                    .loginPage("/admin/login")
                    .failureUrl("/admin/login?failed")
                    .loginProcessingUrl("/admin/login/process")
                    .permitAll()
                    
            ).logout((logout) ->
                logout
                    .deleteCookies("JSESSIONID")
                    .invalidateHttpSession(true)
                    .logoutUrl("/api/auth/logout")
                    .logoutSuccessUrl("/logout-success")
                    
            ).headers((headers) ->
                headers
                    .frameOptions(frameOptions -> frameOptions.sameOrigin())
            )
        ;
        return http.build();
}

I tested putting my "admin/login.html" in "/resources, /resources/static and /resources/templates" (like console log show) but continue not working in any of this directories.

comments.body_markdown: I'm not sure this is a [mre] at this point. Since the private key is actually PKCS#1 formatted rather than PKCS#8 formatted this would normally throw an exception in `KeyFactory.generatePrivate`. If, however, one adds the Bouncycastle provider to the provider list then `KeyFactory.generatePrivate` will work as apparently the Bouncycastle provider is more tolerant in what it accepts in a PKCS8EncodedKeySpec.
comments.body: I'm not sure this is a minimal reproducible example at this point. Since the private key is actually PKCS#1 formatted rather than PKCS#8 formatted this would normally throw an exception in KeyFactory.generatePrivate. If, however, one adds the Bouncycastle provider to the provider list then KeyFactory.generatePrivate will work as apparently the Bouncycastle provider is more tolerant in what it accepts in a PKCS8EncodedKeySpec.

answers.title: Can we get the items in combo to be displayed in a checkbox in Java SWT?
answers.body:
Use getSelectionIndex to get the selection index in the first Combo.

Something like:

Label item = new Label(shell, SWT.NONE);
item.setText("Item");

Combo comboitem = new Combo(shell, SWT.NONE | SWT.READ_ONLY);
comboitem.setItems("A", "B", "C");

Label list = new Label(shell, SWT.NONE);
list.setText("List");
Combo combolist = new Combo(shell, SWT.NONE | SWT.READ_ONLY);

comboitem.addSelectionListener(new SelectionAdapter()
{
  @Override
  public void widgetSelected(final SelectionEvent e) {

    switch (comboitem.getSelectionIndex())
    {
      case 0 -> combolist.setItems("AA", "AB", "AC");
      case 1 -> combolist.setItems("BA", "BB", "BC", "BD");
      case 2 -> combolist.setItems("CA", "CB", "CC", "CD");
    }

    combolist.select(0);
  }});

Note that you also need to call select(0) to make the first item of the list visible in the combo.

I have used the enhanced switch syntax here which needs a modern version of Java - it will need small changes for older versions of Java.

Alternatively this uses a checkbox Table and resets the items:

final Combo comboitem = new Combo(shell, SWT.NONE | SWT.READ_ONLY);
comboitem.setItems("A", "B", "C");

final Table table = new Table(shell, SWT.CHECK | SWT.BORDER);

// Assumes parent Composite is using GridLayout. Adjust as required
final GridData data = new GridData(SWT.BEGINNING, SWT.TOP, false, false);
data.heightHint = 100;
data.widthHint = 100;
table.setLayoutData(data);

comboitem.addSelectionListener(new SelectionAdapter()
{
  @Override
  public void widgetSelected(final SelectionEvent e) {

    switch (comboitem.getSelectionIndex())
    {
      case 0 -> createItems(table, "AA", "AB", "AC");
      case 1 -> createItems(table, "BA", "BB", "BC", "BD");
      case 2 -> createItems(table, "CA", "CB", "CC", "CD");
    }
 }});

  private static void createItems(final Table table, final String... items)
  {
    table.removeAll();

    for (final String item : items) {
      final TableItem tableItem = new TableItem(table, SWT.NONE);
      tableItem.setText(item);
    }
  }

answers.title: Finding path in 2D array using BFS
answers.body:
the code you are using is DFS, deep-first search instead of BFS.

And your code is almost correct by the means of DFS, however your use of the "visited" parameter is not correct, which is the cause of the whole algorithm's wrong. The "visited" parameter is usually a map of your visited nodes, and better to be a bool matrix same as the original graph (your 2D array), because you want to uniquely mark the nodes you have visited. However you converted the position into a single value:

int position = x * cols + y;

which can not uniquely mark the nodes you have visited. just for example:

1*20 + 0

is the same as

0*20 + 20

but they are two different positions in the graph...

So in your case, you can use:

boolean[][] visited = new boolean[rows][cols];

to track your visited nodes. And your code can be refactored to this:

    public static List<List<int[]>> findPossiblePaths(int[][] matrix) {
            int rows = matrix.length;
            int cols = matrix[0].length;
            boolean[][] visited = new boolean[rows][cols];
            int[][] directions = {{0, 1}, {1, 0}, {0, -1}, {-1, 0}};

            List<List<int[]>> paths = new ArrayList<>();
            List<int[]> currentPath = new ArrayList<>();
            dfs(matrix, 0, 0, 0, visited, directions, currentPath, paths);
            return paths;
    }

    private static void dfs(int[][] matrix, int x, int y, int stationCount, boolean[][] visited, int[][] directions,
                            List<int[]> currentPath, List<List<int[]>> paths) {
        int rows = matrix.length;
        int cols = matrix[0].length;

        if (x == rows - 1 && y == cols - 1 && stationCount == 4) {
            paths.add(new ArrayList<>(currentPath));
            return;
        }

        visited[x][y]=true;
        currentPath.add(new int[]{x, y});

        for (int[] dir : directions) {
            int newX = x + dir[0];
            int newY = y + dir[1];

            if (newX >= 0 && newX < rows && newY >= 0 && newY < cols && !visited[newX][newY]
                    && matrix[newX][newY] != 1) {
                int newStationCount = stationCount + (matrix[newX][newY] == 2 ? 1 : 0);

                if (newStationCount <= 4) {
                    dfs(matrix, newX, newY, newStationCount, visited, directions, currentPath, paths);
                }
            }
        }

        visited[x][y]=false;
        currentPath.remove(currentPath.size() - 1);
    }

And another suggestion is that you can make the matrix, directions, and visited parameters as class member variables instead of parameters, which can make your dfs function's signature simpler.

    public static List<List<int[]>> findPossiblePaths(int[][] matrix) {
        int rows = matrix.length;
        int cols = matrix[0].length;
        int gridSize = rows * cols;
        BitSet[] visited = new BitSet[gridSize];
        for (int i = 0; i < gridSize; i++) {
            visited[i] = new BitSet(5); // Track station count from 0 to 4
        }
        int[][] directions = {{0, 1}, {1, 0}, {0, -1}, {-1, 0}};

        List<List<int[]>> paths = new ArrayList<>();

    private static void dfs(int[][] matrix, int x, int y, int stationCount, BitSet[] visited, int[][] directions,
                            List<int[]> currentPath, List<List<int[]>> paths) {
        int rows = matrix.length;
        int cols = matrix[0].length;
        int position = x * cols + y;

        if (x == rows - 1 && y == cols - 1 && stationCount == 4) {

                    && matrix[newX][newY] != 1) {
                int newStationCount = stationCount + (matrix[newX][newY] == 2 ? 1 : 0);

                if (newStationCount <= 4) {
                    dfs(matrix, newX, newY, newStationCount, visited, directions, currentPath, paths);
                }
            }
        }

        visited[position].clear(stationCount);
        currentPath.remove(currentPath.size() - 1);
    }

            return matrix;
        } catch (FileNotFoundException e) {
            System.out.println("Failed to read array from file: " + e.getMessage());
            return null;

    }
}

answers.title: How to validate xml against xsd and get *ALL* errors?
answers.body:
Between Validator validator = schema.newValidator(); and StreamSource xmlFile = new StreamSource(xml); add this fragment:

  final List<SAXParseException> exceptions = new LinkedList<SAXParseException>();
  validator.setErrorHandler(new ErrorHandler()
  {
    @Override
    public void warning(SAXParseException exception) throws SAXException
    {
      exceptions.add(exception);
    }

    @Override
    public void fatalError(SAXParseException exception) throws SAXException
    {
      exceptions.add(exception);
    }

    @Override
    public void error(SAXParseException exception) throws SAXException
    {
      exceptions.add(exception);
    }
  });

This way, after validate() you'll get full list of exceptions, but if one fatal error occurs, the parsing stops...

EDIT: the JavaDoc says: The application must assume that the document is unusable after the parser has invoked this method, and should continue (if at all) only for the sake of collecting additional error messages: in fact, SAX parsers are free to stop reporting any other events once this method has been invoked. So fatalError() may or may not cause the parsing to stop.

items.title: How to validate xml against xsd and get *ALL* errors?

I have a standard code like below to validate xml against xsd, but it throw exception on first error and stops. How to validate xml, but continue on the first and next errors and get them all at the end ? Is it even possible ?

public static void validate(File xml, InputStream xsd) {
    try {
        SchemaFactory factory = SchemaFactory.newInstance(XMLConstants.W3C_XML_SCHEMA_NS_URI);
        Schema schema = factory.newSchema(new StreamSource(xsd));
        Validator validator = schema.newValidator();
        StreamSource xmlFile = new StreamSource(xml);
        validator.validate(xmlFile);

    } catch (SAXException e) {
        e.printStackTrace();
    } catch (IOException e) {
        e.printStackTrace();
    }
}

answers.title: How can I read files from Zip file to memory with Java?
answers.body:
Well, just change the part that writes the file into something you want to do with the data.

while((entry = zis.getNextEntry()) != null) {
    System.out.println("Extracting: " + entry);
    int count;
    byte[] data = new byte[BUFFER];
    String filename = entry.getName();
    System.out.println("Filename: " + filename);
    while ((count = zis.read(data, 0, BUFFER)) != -1) {
       // Do whatever you want with the data variable
       System.out.println(data);
    }
}

answers.body_markdown: This process reads the whole zip file and just dumps it to a stream, it does not read/split the individual files within the zip. Its sad that the ZIP library does not provide one with the inputstream of each individual file within the ZIP stream.

items.title: How can I read files from Zip file to memory with Java?
items.body:
I found example from SUN site (http://java.sun.com/developer/technicalArticles/Programming/compression/), but it returns BufferedOutputStream. But I would like to get ZipEntry file as InputStream and then process next file. Is that possible? My program has no access to harddisk, so it cannot even temporarily save files.

import java.io.*;
import java.util.zip.*;

public class UnZip {
   final int BUFFER = 2048;
   public static void main (String argv[]) {
      try {
         BufferedOutputStream dest = null;
         FileInputStream fis = new 
       FileInputStream(argv[0]);
         ZipInputStream zis = new 
       ZipInputStream(new BufferedInputStream(fis));
         ZipEntry entry;
         while((entry = zis.getNextEntry()) != null) {
            System.out.println("Extracting: " +entry);
            int count;
            byte data[] = new byte[BUFFER];
            // write the files to the disk
            FileOutputStream fos = new 
          FileOutputStream(entry.getName());
            dest = new 
              BufferedOutputStream(fos, BUFFER);
            while ((count = zis.read(data, 0, BUFFER)) 
              != -1) {
               dest.write(data, 0, count);
            }
            dest.flush();
            dest.close();
         }
         zis.close();
      } catch(Exception e) {
         e.printStackTrace();
      }
   }
}

answers.body_markdown:
**Guys problem solved! I will try to explain better**

The error message received, `java.lang.ClassCastException`, indicates that there was a problem with casting types in code. Specifically, it seems that tried to convert an object of type ``org.hibernate.hql.internal.ast.tree.SqlNode`` to ``org.hibernate.hql.internal.ast.tree.FromReferenceNode``, but these two types are incompatible and cannot be directly cast to each other.

To fix the issue, Instead of directly executing the query using ``entityManager.createQuery(queryString)``, i took the following steps:

Created a separate query object by assigning ``entityManager.createQuery(queryString)`` to it.

It's important to be aware that exceptions like ``ClassCastException`` occur when there is a mismatch between the expected types of objects. In this case, the ``createQuery()`` method returned an object of type SqlNode, which was incompatible with the expected type of ``FromReferenceNode``. This caused the casting error.

By creating a separate query object and setting the parameters directly on it, you work around the casting issue and successfully execute the update query. Additionally, you added exception handling to catch any potential errors that may occur during the update process.

I hope this explanation helps others who may encounter a similar issue to understand the problem and implement the solution in their own code.

In short, it is linked to the incorrect use of the ``entityManager``

    suspend fun updateProgress() {
        try {
            val entityManager = HibernateUtils.createEntityManager()
            entityManager.transaction.begin()
    
            val queryString = "UPDATE ServerDailyQuest SET current = :current, new = :new, completed = :completed WHERE id = :id"
    
            withContext(Dispatchers.IO) {
                val query = entityManager.createQuery(queryString)
                    .setParameter("current", current)
                    .setParameter("new", new)
                    .setParameter("completed", completed)
                    .setParameter("id", id)
    
                val rowCount = query.executeUpdate()
                println("Rows updated: $rowCount")
            }
    
            entityManager.transaction.commit()
            entityManager.close()
        } catch (ex: Exception) {
            println("Error occurred while updating progress: $ex")
        }
      }

Using ``try`` and ``catch`` is a way to handle exceptions in code. In the provided code snippet, try and catch are used to capture and handle any exceptions that may occur during the execution of the ``updateProgress()`` function.

Overall, ``try`` and ``catch`` are used to provide robustness and error handling capabilities to ensure the program can gracefully recover from exceptions and continue its execution.

Hope this helps

comments.body_markdown: yes, it's multithreaded check this example https://www.baeldung.com/java-when-to-use-parallel-stream#2-parallel-streams
comments.body: yes, it's multithreaded check this example baeldung.com/…

comments.body_markdown: Why do you think it would not be "truly multithreaded"? This seems like an odd question. There isn't a guarantee that the actions will be done in parallel, but in practice they will be depending on hardware limitations.
comments.body: Why do you think it would not be "truly multithreaded"? This seems like an odd question. There isn't a guarantee that the actions will be done in parallel, but in practice they will be depending on hardware limitations.

comments.body_markdown: What is your definition of multi-threaded; versus _truly_ multi-threaded?
comments.body: What is your definition of multi-threaded; versus truly multi-threaded?

answers.body_markdown:
The execution will be truly multithreaded if the application is run in a multi-processor environment. The order of execution is not predictable. I have observed that the stream gets partitioned into no more than 32 parts and is executed on as many threads as there are processors (this is a JRE implementation detail that may be different in your environment, I have not run tests on more than 8 processors).

After that, the next thing that affects the order of execution is the way the Spliterator partitions the data. Most obvious way would be to split it into four equal sized parts, but we cannot know that unless we have access to the source code.

Then the way the split streams are assigned to the threads is also implementation dependant.

Then there are almost always other processes or threads running in the environment that might require processor time and delay the execution of any of the split streams.

In parallel computing, if you need to guarantee the order of execution, you need to implement flow control structures like semaphors.
answers.title: Will Java Parallel Stream pick next task after current is done?
answers.body:
The execution will be truly multithreaded if the application is run in a multi-processor environment. The order of execution is not predictable. I have observed that the stream gets partitioned into no more than 32 parts and is executed on as many threads as there are processors (this is a JRE implementation detail that may be different in your environment, I have not run tests on more than 8 processors).

After that, the next thing that affects the order of execution is the way the Spliterator partitions the data. Most obvious way would be to split it into four equal sized parts, but we cannot know that unless we have access to the source code.

Then the way the split streams are assigned to the threads is also implementation dependant.

Then there are almost always other processes or threads running in the environment that might require processor time and delay the execution of any of the split streams.

In parallel computing, if you need to guarantee the order of execution, you need to implement flow control structures like semaphors.

answers.title: @JsonIgnoreProperties and anything for controlling JSON doesn't work at Spring boot
answers.body:
You have to use @JsonManagedReference and @JsonBackReference at the same time which I don't see in your source code.

@JsonManagedReference - Using this , Jackson takes the forward part of the reference (e.g. your Set<Attendance> attendance in Lesson class), and converts it in a json-like storage format; this is the so-called marshalling process.

@JsonBackReference - With this, Jackson looks for the back part of the reference (e.g. Lesson lesson in Attendance class) and leaves it as it is, not serializing it.

Try the below and it should work.

Attendance

@Entity
@Setter
@Getter
@Builder
@NoArgsConstructor
@AllArgsConstructor
public class Attendance extends BaseEntity {

    @ManyToOne(cascade = CascadeType.ALL, fetch = FetchType.EAGER)
    @JsonBackReference
    Lesson lesson;

    @ManyToOne
    @JsonBackReference
    Student student;

    @OneToOne
    @JsonBackReference
    CanceledLesson canceledLesson;

    Boolean didAttend;
}

Lesson

@Entity
@Setter
@Getter
@SuperBuilder
@NoArgsConstructor
@Inheritance(strategy = InheritanceType.JOINED)
public abstract class Lesson {

    @Id
    @GeneratedValue(strategy = GenerationType.TABLE)
    Long id;
    @Enumerated(EnumType.STRING)
    @Column(name = "time", columnDefinition = "ENUM ('am0915', 'am1000', 'am1045', 'am1130', 'pm1205', 'pm0105', 'pm0150', 'pm0235', 'pm0320', 'pm0405', 'pm0450', 'pm0535', 'pm0620', 'pm0705', 'pm0750') not null", nullable = false)
    LessonTimes time;

    @DateTimeFormat(pattern = "yyyy-MM-dd")
    @JsonFormat(pattern = "yyyy-MM-dd")
    public LocalDate date;

    @ManyToOne
    @JsonBackReference
    Teacher teacher;

    @OneToMany(mappedBy = "lesson")
    @JsonManagedReference
    private Set<Attendance> attendance;

    public Set<Student> getStudents() {
        return this.getAttendance().stream().map(Attendance::getStudent).collect(Collectors.toSet());
    }

    public void setStudents(Set<Student> studentSet) {
        var attendance = studentSet.stream().map(student -> Attendance.builder()
                .lesson(this)
                .student(student)
                .build()
        ).collect(Collectors.toSet());
        this.setAttendance(attendance);
    }
}

Student

@Entity
@Table(name = "students")
@Getter
@Setter
@NoArgsConstructor
@SuperBuilder
@JsonIgnoreProperties(value = {"role", "canceledLessons", "authorities", "lessons", "events", "lessonCredits", "coachings", "competitionMember"}, allowGetters = true)
public class Student extends JwtUser {

    public Student(Long id) {
        super(id);
    }

    public Student(JwtUser jwtUser) {
        super(jwtUser);
    }

    {
        this.setRole(Set.of(Role.ROLE_USER));
        this.setPosition(Position.Student);
    }

    String phoneNumber;
    String telegram;
    String workAddress;
    String homeAddress;
    String danceLevel;

    @CreationTimestamp
    @Column(updatable = false)
    Timestamp registered;


    @OneToMany(mappedBy = "student")
    @JsonManagedReference
    Set<Attendance> attendance;

    @OneToMany(fetch = FetchType.EAGER, mappedBy = "student")
    @JsonManagedReference
    private Set<NoteAboutStudent> noteAboutStudent;

    @ManyToMany
    @JsonManagedReference
    @JoinTable(name = "students_coachings",
            joinColumns = @JoinColumn(name = "student_id"),
            inverseJoinColumns = @JoinColumn(name = "coaching_id"))
    Set<Coaching> coachings;

    @OneToMany(mappedBy = "student")
    @JsonManagedReference
    Set<CompetitionMember> competitionMember;


    @ManyToMany
    @JoinTable(name = "students_events",
            joinColumns = @JoinColumn(name = "student_id"),
            inverseJoinColumns = @JoinColumn(name = "event_id"))
    Set<Event> events = new HashSet<>();

    @OneToMany(mappedBy = "student")
    @JsonManagedReference
    Set<LessonCredit> lessonCredits;

    public void addCompetition(CompetitionMember cm) {
        if (this.competitionMember == null) {
            this.competitionMember = new HashSet<>();
        }
        cm.setStudent(this);
        this.competitionMember.add(cm);
    }

    public Set<Lesson> getLessons() {
        return this.getAttendance().stream().map(Attendance::getLesson).collect(Collectors.toSet());
    }
}

items.title: @JsonIgnoreProperties and anything for controlling JSON doesn't work at Spring boot
items.body:
I'm facing a circular reference problem when attempting to serialize my entities using Jackson and Hibernate. The application throws a StackOverflowError with the error message: "Infinite recursion."

I have a bidirectional relationship between the Lesson, Student and Attendance entities, where Attendance can have multiple students, and a lesson can have multiple attendance. The entities are mapped using JPA annotations, and I'm using Jackson for JSON serialization.

2023-05-28 19:39:09.548 DEBUG 15011 --- [nio-4800-exec-3] s.s.w.c.SecurityContextPersistenceFilter : Cleared SecurityContextHolder to complete request
2023-05-28 19:39:09.549 ERROR 15011 --- [nio-4800-exec-3] o.a.c.c.C.[.[.[/].[dispatcherServlet]    : Servlet.service() for servlet [dispatcherServlet] in context with path [] threw exception [Request processing failed; nested exception is org.springframework.http.converter.HttpMessageNotWritableException: Could not write JSON: Infinite recursion (StackOverflowError); nested exception is com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.JsonMappingException: Infinite recursion (StackOverflowError) (through reference chain: java.util.HashSet[0]->com.example.demo.domains.users.Student["attendance"]->org.hibernate.collection.internal.PersistentSet[0]->com.example.demo.domains.lessons.Attendance["lesson"]->com.example.demo.domains.lessons.PlainLesson["students"]->java.util.HashSet[0]->com.example.demo.domains.users.Student["attendance"]->org.hibernate.collection.internal.PersistentSet[0]->com.example.demo.domains.lessons.Attendance["lesson"]->com.example.demo.domains.lessons.PlainLesson["students"]->java.util.HashSet[0]->com.example.demo.domains.users.Student["attendance"]->org.hibernate.collection.internal.PersistentSet[0]->com.example.demo.domains.lessons.Attendance["lesson"]->com.example.demo.domains.lessons.PlainLesson["students"]->java.util.HashSet[0]->com.example.demo.domains.users.Student["attendance"]->org.hibernate.collection.internal.PersistentSet[0]->com.example.demo.domains.lessons.Attendance["lesson"]->com.example.demo.domains.lessons.PlainLesson["students"]->java.util.HashSet[0]->com.example.demo.domains.users.Student["attendance"]-> ... 
->com.example.demo.domains.lessons.PlainLesson["students"])] with root cause

java.lang.StackOverflowError: null
    at java.base/java.lang.ClassLoader.defineClass1(Native Method) ~[na:na]
    at java.base/java.lang.ClassLoader.defineClass(ClassLoader.java:1013) ~[na:na]
    at java.base/java.security.SecureClassLoader.defineClass(SecureClassLoader.java:150) ~[na:na]
    at java.base/jdk.internal.loader.BuiltinClassLoader.defineClass(BuiltinClassLoader.java:862) ~[na:na]
    at java.base/jdk.internal.loader.BuiltinClassLoader.findClassOnClassPathOrNull(BuiltinClassLoader.java:760) ~[na:na]
    at java.base/jdk.internal.loader.BuiltinClassLoader.loadClassOrNull(BuiltinClassLoader.java:681) ~[na:na]
    at java.base/jdk.internal.loader.BuiltinClassLoader.loadClass(BuiltinClassLoader.java:639) ~[na:na]
    at java.base/jdk.internal.loader.ClassLoaders$AppClassLoader.loadClass(ClassLoaders.java:188) ~[na:na]
    at java.base/java.lang.ClassLoader.loadClass(ClassLoader.java:521) ~[na:na]

I have tried various approaches to handle the circular reference issue, including using @JsonIgnore, @JsonIgnoreProperties, @JsonBackReference, @JsonManagedReference, @JsonIdentityInfo, and even custom serializers and deserializers. However, none of these solutions have resolved the problem.

I suspect that there might be other factors contributing to the issue, or I might be missing something in my code configuration. I would greatly appreciate any insights, suggestions, or alternative approaches to resolve this circular reference problem and enable successful serialization of my entities.

I can provide the relevant code snippets and the full stack trace of the exception if needed.

Here is code sources: Attendance

import com.example.demo.BaseEntity;

    @ManyToOne(cascade = CascadeType.ALL, fetch = FetchType.EAGER)
    @JsonIgnoreProperties(value = {"attendance"})
    Lesson lesson;

    @ManyToOne
    @JsonIgnoreProperties(value = {"lessons", "authorities", "roles", "events", "coachings", "competitionMember", "attendance", "student"})
    Student student;

    @OneToOne
    @JsonIgnore
    CanceledLesson canceledLesson;

    Boolean didAttend;
}

items.title: Using JSTL to compare strings keeps failing
items.body:
Using JSTL to compare strings keeps failing.

Environment TOMCAT 7.0.47 JRE6

I have already imported the taglib:

<%@ taglib prefix="c" uri="http://java.sun.com/jsp/jstl/core" %>

Here is the code:

    <c:forEach var="result" items="${resultList}">
        <tr>
            <td>${result.DIV}</td>
            <td>${result.DIV_NAME}</td>
            <td>${result.STAFF_CODE}</td>
            <td>${result.STAFF_NAME}</td>
             <td>
                <c:choose>
                    <c:when test="${result.STAFF_TYPE == 'DOC'}">DOCTOR</c:when>
                    <c:when test="${result.STAFF_TYPE == 'RES'}">RESIDENT</c:when>
                    <c:when test="${result.STAFF_TYPE == 'TRE'}">TRAINEE</c:when>
                    <c:otherwise>no</c:otherwise>
                </c:choose>
            </td>
            <td>${result.STAFF_FLAG == 1 ? 'A' : (result.STAFF_FLAG == 2 ? 'B' : '其他')}</td>
        </tr>
    </c:forEach>

The result.STAFF_TYPE part keeps failing and always goes into the <c:otherwise> block, displaying "no" on the page.

However, the result.STAFF_FLAG part works fine and shows 'A' or 'B' as expected.

I have already tried the following:

  • Changing == to eq:
<c:when test="${result.STAFF_TYPE eq 'DOC'}">DOCTOR</c:when>

But it didn't make any difference.

  • Printing out result.STAFF_TYPE to check if I really received the data:
<c:otherwise>${result.STAFF_TYPE}</c:otherwise>

This correctly showed 'DOC', 'RES', 'TRE', which means I am indeed receiving the data.

I have read the following articles:

  • How to use if-else option in JSTL

  • How to compare parameters in JSTL

  • JSTL string comparison always returns false

Any help would be greatly appreciated.

Thanks.

answers.title: How can I use a while loop in java to find the sum of all numbers between 0 and a given integer?
answers.body:
Note that your while-loop is commented-out.

Here is a Java tutorial on while and do-while loops.
The while and do-while Statements (The Java™ Tutorials > Learning the Java Language > Language Basics).

In Java, to create a while-loop, you use the following structure.

while (i < end) {

}

To derive a sum of values, from i to an exclusive end, you can use the following.

sum = sum + i;
i = i + 1;

To return the sum value, you use

return sum;

All together the code for the whileExample method would be as follows.

int whileExample(int end) {
    int sum = 0;
    int i = 0;
    while (i < end) {
        sum = sum + i;
        i = i + 1;
    }
    return sum;
}

answers.title: Use TypeConverter or break single class into multiple classes?
answers.body:
Would I want to use a TypeConverter for this field, or would it be better break it out into it's own class and do a one to many relationship? In short there are proponents for both.

My question is how do I want to handle Entities with ArrayLists most efficiently in a Room Database?

if efficiency is the criteria then I would suggest that utilising the relational aspect, i.e. a table for the related data, of the database is more efficient as you do not have to store additional data, bloat and that as SQLite is a relational database and additional that SQLite utilises C rather than Java is more efficient at storing and accessing the related data.

I'm just not sure what Room is doing in the background when you implement a TypeConverter.

Room simply invokes the respective defined TypeConverter to save data and to retrieve the data.

SQLite, the actual database that Room uses, can store specific types of data per column. It can be

  1. an INTEGER type,
  2. a REAL type (decimal),
  3. a TEXT type (String) or a BLOB type
  4. a BLOB type (a stream of bytes, such as a ByteArray)
  5. a NULL,
  6. a NUMERIC type (which is a default type and is not supported by ROOM)

If an field is not one of these types then it needs to be converted to one of these types.

Obviously NULL is of no use as it is a single value. INTEGER although it can store very large values is very likely not usable without a suitable algorithm. REAL, likewise would require such an algorithm. So really to save such a field either requires conversion of the field, an object, into either a byte stream or a String.

Typically a JSON representation of the object is stored as it is a commonly used method of passing objects from one place to another.

A TypeConverter always requires a pair of converters (methods annotated with the @TypeConverter annotation note the singular)

  • one to convert the object to the single value that can be stored, and
  • the other to return the object from the single value.

The class(es) in which the TypeConverters are defined have to be defined using the @TypeConverters annotation note the plural and have sufficient scope (at the @Database level provides the greatest scope).

Perhaps consider the following based upon your class (with many fields removed to simply matters):-

@Entity(tableName = "spot_table")
public class Spot {

   @PrimaryKey
   @NonNull
   private int id;
   private String name;
   private ArrayList<LocalDate> observedDates;


   public int getId() {
      return id;
   }
   public void setId(int id) {
      this.id = id;
   }
   public String getName() {
      return name;
   }
   public void setName(String name) {
      this.name = name;
   }
   public ArrayList<LocalDate> getObservedDates() {
      return observedDates;
   }
   public void setObservedDates(ArrayList<LocalDate> observedDates) {
      this.observedDates = observedDates;
   }

   /* Useless Type Converters */
   @TypeConverter
   public String convertArrayListLocalDateToString(ArrayList<LocalDate> observedDates) {
      return "blah";
   }
   @TypeConverter
   public ArrayList<LocalDate> convertStringToArayListLocalDate(String retrievedFromDatabase) {
      return new ArrayList<LocalDate>();
   }
}
  • note that the TypeConverters are:-

    • inlcuded in the Spot class (they could be elsewhere and typically are in a class of their own)

    • are useless as the data will always be stored as blah and retreived as an empty ArrayList.

    • highlighting that Room knows nothing about how the data is convertered just that it is.

Now consider the following @Dao annotated abstract class (could be an interface but abstract classed allow methods with bodies which can be useful):-

@Dao
abstract class AllDAOs {

   @Insert
   abstract long insert(Spot spot);
   @Query("SELECT * FROM spot_table")
   abstract List<Spot> getAllSpots();
}
  • i.e. nothing at all special a plain convenience insert and query

Lastly, in conjunction with the above, an @Database annotated class that also has the @TypeConverters annotation to define the Spot class as containing TypeConverters:-

@TypeConverters(value = {Spot.class})
@Database(entities = {Spot.class}, exportSchema = false, version = 1)
abstract class TheDatabase extends RoomDatabase {
    abstract AllDAOs getAllDAOs();
}

After compiling the project then the generated java class AllDAOs_Impl (i.e. the @Dao annotated class suffixed with _Impl) includes the following code:-

final String _tmp = __spot.convertArrayListLocalDateToString(entity.getObservedDates());
....
_tmpObservedDates = __spot.convertStringToArayListLocalDate(_tmp);
  • The first line in the code for inserting, the second line in the code that extracts the data.
  • i.e. Room just includes the method calls, what they do (in this case a load of rubbish data wise) is not checked at any greater level other than the signature of the methods.

As you are saving a list of dates then you could simply save a CSV of the dates. So instead of the useless converters above you could instead have something like:-

@TypeConverter
public String convertLocalDateArrayToString(ArrayList<LocalDate> observedDates) {
    StringBuilder rv = new StringBuilder();
    for(int i=0; i<observedDates.size(); i++) {
        if (i>0) rv.append(",");
        rv.append(observedDates.get(i).toString());
    }
    return rv.toString();
}
@TypeConverter
public ArrayList<LocalDate> convertStringToLocalDateArray(String databaseValue) {
    ArrayList<LocalDate> rv = new ArrayList<>();
    String[] stringArray = databaseValue.split(",");
    for (String s: stringArray) {
        rv.add(LocalDate.parse(s,formatter));
    }
    return rv;
}

  • this has minimal bloat i.e. just a comma between each item and would thus be more efficient than converting to a JSON representation using one of the available JSON libraries.

  • where formatter is, for example, DateTimeFormatter formatter = DateTimeFormatter.ISO_LOCAL_DATE;

  • again showing that Room does not attempt to interrogate what the converter actually does.

  • In this case the data in the database could, for example, be:-

The above data inserted using (and then extracted) using (with @Database modified to get a singleton of the database):-

    db = TheDatabase.getInstance(this);
    dao = db.getAllDAOs();

    LocalDate ld01 = LocalDate.now();
    LocalDate ld02 = LocalDate.now().plusDays(7);
    LocalDate ld03 = LocalDate.now().plusMonths(5);
    ArrayList<LocalDate> ald = new ArrayList<>();
    ald.add(ld01);

    Spot aSpot = new Spot();
    aSpot.setId(1);
    aSpot.setName("Test1");
    aSpot.setObservedDates(ald);
    dao.insert(aSpot);
    aSpot.setId(2);
    aSpot.setName("Test2");
    ald.add(ld02);
    dao.insert(aSpot);
    aSpot.setId(3);
    aSpot.setName("Test3");
    ald.add(ld03);
    dao.insert(aSpot);


    for(Spot s: dao.getAllSpots()) {
        StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder();
        for (LocalDate  ld: s.getObservedDates()) {
            sb.append("\n\tDATE IS ").append(ld.format(Spot.formatter));
        }
        Log.d("SPOTINFO","Spot ID is" + s.getId() + " NAME is " + s.getName() + " There are " + s.getObservedDates().size() + " OBSERVED DATES. They are:-" + sb.toString());
    }

The log from the above includes:-

D/SPOTINFO: Spot ID is1 NAME is Test1 There are 1 OBSERVED DATES. They are:-
        DATE IS 2023-05-29
D/SPOTINFO: Spot ID is2 NAME is Test2 There are 2 OBSERVED DATES. They are:-
        DATE IS 2023-05-29
        DATE IS 2023-06-05
D/SPOTINFO: Spot ID is3 NAME is Test3 There are 3 OBSERVED DATES. They are:-
        DATE IS 2023-05-29
        DATE IS 2023-06-05
        DATE IS 2023-10-29

**The equivalent with TypeConverters. i.e. using a 1 to many relationship.

In this case a second table (od) will exist for storing the observed dates as a String (more efficient if long/Long but for brevity and ease of demo dates as string are easier to view).

So another class would be required e.g.

@Entity(
        tableName = "od",
        foreignKeys = {
                @ForeignKey(
                        entity = Spot.class,
                        parentColumns = {"id"},
                        childColumns = {"parentSpotId"},
                        onUpdate = ForeignKey.CASCADE,
                        onDelete = ForeignKey.CASCADE
                )
        }
)
class ObservedDate {
    @PrimaryKey
    Long odId=null;
    @ColumnInfo(index = true)
    long parentSpotId;
    String date;

    public Long getOdId() {
        return odId;
    }

    public void setOdId(Long odId) {
        this.odId = odId;
    }

    public String getDate() {
        return date;
    }

    public void setDate(String date) {
        this.date = date;
    }

    public long getParentSpotId() {
        return parentSpotId;
    }

    public void setParentSpotId(long parentSpotId) {
        this.parentSpotId = parentSpotId;
    }
    ObservedDate(){}

    @Ignore
    ObservedDate(long parentSpotId, String date) {
        this.date = date;
        this.parentSpotId = parentSpotId;
    }
}
  • Note that Foreign Keys are not compulsory. However, suggested as they enforce referential integrity.
    • Within Foreign Keys OnDelete and OnUpdate actions are optional. CASCADE helps to maintain referential integrity.

Now a DAO method will be required to insert ObservedDates so:-

@Insert(onConflict = OnConflictStrategy.IGNORE)
abstract long insert(ObservedDate od);

As you would typically want to get a Spot with the child ObservedDates then a POJO that embeds the single parent (Spot) and relates the respective children (List of ObservedDates):-

class SpotWithObservedDates {
   @Embedded
   Spot spot;
   @Relation(
           entity = ObservedDate.class,
           parentColumn = "id",
           entityColumn = "parentSpotId"
   )
   List<ObservedDate> observedDateList;
}

The @Embedded and @Relation tell Room how to get the children for the adult. So all you need to get (in this case all Spots with the children) is a Query that returns a list of the SpotWithObservedDates objects. So in the @Dao:-

@Query("SELECT * FROM spot_table")
abstract List<SpotWithObservedDates> getAllSpotsWithObservedDates();
  • Note that the Spot class has not been changed so the TypeConverted list still remains You wouldn't do this if publishing the App. But for demonstration both methodologies present allows comparisons.

So the activity code could be extended to be :-

    db = TheDatabase.getInstance(this);
    dao = db.getAllDAOs();

    LocalDate ld01 = LocalDate.now();
    LocalDate ld02 = LocalDate.now().plusDays(7);
    LocalDate ld03 = LocalDate.now().plusMonths(5);
    ArrayList<LocalDate> ald = new ArrayList<>();
    ald.add(ld01);

    Spot aSpot = new Spot();
    aSpot.setId(1);
    aSpot.setName("Test1");
    aSpot.setObservedDates(ald);
    dao.insert(aSpot);
    aSpot.setId(2);
    aSpot.setName("Test2");
    ald.add(ld02);
    dao.insert(aSpot);
    aSpot.setId(3);
    aSpot.setName("Test3");
    ald.add(ld03);
    dao.insert(aSpot);


    /* Do the equivalent of the above but with the od table */
    /* note that the Spot rows already exist */
    dao.insert(new ObservedDate(1, ld01.format(Spot.formatter)));
    dao.insert(new ObservedDate(2,ld01.format(Spot.formatter)));
    dao.insert(new ObservedDate(2,ld02.format(Spot.formatter)));
    dao.insert(new ObservedDate(aSpot.getId(),ld01.format(Spot.formatter)));
    dao.insert(new ObservedDate(aSpot.getId(),ld02.format(Spot.formatter)));
    dao.insert(new ObservedDate(aSpot.getId(),ld03.format(Spot.formatter)));


    for(Spot s: dao.getAllSpots()) {
        StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder();
        for (LocalDate  ld: s.getObservedDates()) {
            sb.append("\n\tDATE IS ").append(ld.format(Spot.formatter));
        }
        Log.d("SPOTINFO","Spot ID is" + s.getId() + " NAME is " + s.getName() + " There are " + s.getObservedDates().size() + " OBSERVED DATES. They are:-" + sb.toString());
    }

    for (SpotWithObservedDates swod: dao.getAllSpotsWithObservedDates()) {
        StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder();
        for (ObservedDate od: swod.observedDateList) {
            sb.append("\n\tDATE IS ").append(od.getDate());
        }
        Log.d("SPOTINFO","Spot ID is" + swod.spot.getId() + " NAME is " + swod.spot.getName() + " There are " + swod.spot.getObservedDates().size() + " OBSERVED DATES. They are:-" + sb.toString());
    }
}

After running the above, then the database now has:-

  • The highlighted data now superfluous as the of table contains:-

  • Where odId is the unique row identifier, parentSpotId is the reference to the parent and date is the single date per an observation.

The Log now includes the additional messages:-

D/SPOTINFO: Spot ID is1 NAME is Test1 There are 1 OBSERVED DATES. They are:-
        DATE IS 2023-05-29
D/SPOTINFO: Spot ID is2 NAME is Test2 There are 2 OBSERVED DATES. They are:-
        DATE IS 2023-05-29
        DATE IS 2023-06-05
D/SPOTINFO: Spot ID is3 NAME is Test3 There are 3 OBSERVED DATES. They are:-
        DATE IS 2023-05-29
        DATE IS 2023-06-05
        DATE IS 2023-10-29

i.e. the end result is exactly the same

items.title: Use TypeConverter or break single class into multiple classes?
items.body:
I'm trying to implement Room in an app that is already in production.

My question is how do I want to handle Entities with ArrayLists most efficiently in a Room Database?

I know my way around SQL and I'm pretty sure want is needed for 'observedDates' is a one to many relationship. I'm just not sure what Room is doing in the background when you implement a TypeConverter. Is it just converting the the arraylist to a string and inserting it as a single field on the table? Or is doing more like creating a separate table with a joining table? Would I want to use a TypeConverter for this field, or would it be better break it out into it's own class and do a one to many relationship?

@NonNull

....}

If you don't include `\\`, which is an escape sequence for the regular expression, you will get a `-` in between every single character of your string. Meaning that if you have:

`my | text`, and you use `regexp_replace(details, "|", "-")`, you will end up with: `-m-y- -|- -t-e-x-t-` because `|` has a special meaning in regular expression (`a|b` -> alternamte - match either `a` or `b`).

Therefore, you must use your second option which will return `my - text`.
answers.title: What is the correct way to use Regex_replace to replace a '|' with a '-' in Spark Java's column named details?
